In Memory of Dame FRANCES GIBBONS | Daughter of ROBERT HALL Esq. of the | Is land | and Wife of Sr WILLIAM GIBBONS Baronet | Speaker of the Assembly. | She was Mother of four Children | of which only one survived Her. | She behaved in the different Relations of Wife & Mother | with the greatest Prudence and the most tender Affection | And after preparing herself through her whole Life | by an exemplary Course of Piety for her latter End | She felt the Approach of it with Christian Resignation | and in joyfull hope of a blessed Resurrection | died December 1. 1757 | Aged 64 Years

Sacred | to the Memory of the Hon: Sr WILLIAM GIBBONS Baronet | who departed this Life the 11th day of April | in the year of our Lord 1700 | in the 67th year of his Age : | After having successively filled | some of the most considerable Offices in the Publick | civil and military, | with Honour to himself and with Advantage to his Country | For the Space of thirty and three years before his Death | He was constantly elected a representative for the Parish of St Peter | in the General Assembly : | and for the last seventeen of those years | He was as constantly elected Speaker of the House | in that Assembly | He disdained ever to make his Seat the Occasion to promote | his private emolument | and shew'd Himself superior to every Species of Reward | but the Applause of his Constituents | In the year 1742 | He was by his Excellency S-- THOMAS ROBINSON Baronet | appointed Colonel of the Leeward Regiment of Foot | which Post however | from an honest dissatisfaction with the Prospect of Affairs | towards the Decline of that Gentleman's Administration | he resigned | But, on a brighter View which open'd to this Island | with the Arrival of his Excellency Mr GRENVILLE | He soon returned with new Honours to the same Command | And in the year 1753 | Having lately been created by his Majesty a Baronet | of the Kingdom of Great Britain | and by his many faithfull Services as well as by that Mark of Royall Favour | pointed out for greater Honours in this Community | He was by that discerning Governour | made Lieutenant General of his Majesty's Forces in this Island | and Master General of the Ordnance | yet under such Preferments | He never once was known to Stoop | to any mean Complyances ; | He had a Soul too great to be employ'd | but for the Publick Good | At length ! | Declining in his Health, tho not depressed in his Ardour | under another Administration, in an inauspicious Hour | He provok'd in high Displeasure. | and | on the 28th day of March proceeding his Departure, | (so close indeed upon the fatal Period. | yet in one bright Moment of his patriot Flame) | He was by the offended Arm of Power | suddenly dismissed from all his Military Services | Unfortunate | in having liv'd so long as to survive | the " Favour of his Chief " | yet happy | in having liv'd possessed to the last | of the Affection of his Country

Inscription: Sacred to the memory | of JOHN PRETTEJOHN, esquire ; | who WAS BORN THE 29th OF OCTOBER 1731, AND DIED THE 29th OF JUNE, 1803 | This monument has been erected by his widow Charlotte Prettejohn | in testimony of the many virtues which adorned his character | and as a token of their affection | which united them on earth | and . . . wants to be perpetuated in. . . ( many lines)
Decoration: woman and urn, crest and arms below

Inscription: To | The Memory of | The Rev JOHN CARTER A.M. | when divine Providence was pleased to | preserve | through ninety years | of the most useful, exemplary, and | irreproachable existence | which came to its earthly termination | October the 21st 1796 | The vestry of this parish | which he had been for almost half a century | The Rector | and for more than half that Period | the faithful Minister | to perpetuate their admiration | of the fine abilities, consummate learning | the splendid assemblage | of every moral Virtue, and Christian Grace | that would have dignified a mitre | so happily concentrated | in the humble unassuming person | of their amiable patron | And | this recording marble | with all the piety of children | the veneration of disciples | and the sensibility of | friends.
Decoration: urn, mantling with crest/arms, wreaths, flowers, scrollwork and foliage

Inscription: Sacred to the Memory of | Thos Carmichaell Esqe; Son of Archibald Carmichaell | & Frances his Wife, formerly Frances Applewhite, who | departed this Life the 11th day of April 1789 aged 52 Years | after having enjoyed uninterruptedly till the fatal sickness of which he died, a Sound Mind with a sound Body although of a grave and serious Deportment, the amiable and convivial Qualities | of an agreeable and interesting Companion were happily | blended alive to all the nobler Feelings of Friendship without | ostentatious parade, his Memory will be cherished without | tenderest Regret by the narrow circle of this respectable Friends | This small but feeble Tribute to his Memory | will be perused | with pleasure by the few who enjoyed the Happiness of his | Acquaintance

Inscription: And also to the Memory of ANN JORDAN his Wife, | (Daughter and Coheiress of JOSEPH DOTTIN and ANN JORDAN,) | who died January 30th 1791, aged 69 Years | (2 lines) |
Also to the Memory of EDWARD JORDAN, | Son of the above EDWARD & ANN JORDAN, he died | December 17th 1799, aged 58 Years

To record the Virtues & perpetuate the Memory | of Mercy his dear beloved Consort, | William Gibbes Alleyne Esq as a Testimony of | Sincere Affection, has erected this | Monument. | After thirteen years of constant uninterrupted | Bliss with a Partner, who by every Endearment, | sweetened the Joys, alleviated the Cares, & | heightened the Pleasures of the nuptial State ; to | his inexpressible Sorrow, and Concern She was | separated from him on Thursday | Aug 25th. 1774 Aged thirty years. | Her Descent from a race of worthy Ancestry | deriving her Lineage from the Honourable | James Dotin, who was President of this Island | three different times, & being the Daughter of the | Honourable John Dotin, a Gentleman who for a | series of years, filled the most distinguished civil, & | military Stations, in our Community, | Gave her that Consequence among us, which is due | to Birth & Rank | (8 lines.)
Decoration: urn, wreath and decorative framework; missing element at base

Inscription: SACRED | to the Rev FRANCIS FITCHATT M.A. | formerly Fellow of St John's College Cambridge | late Chaplain to the House of Assembly | of this Island | and for 25 Years successively Rector | of St Josephs, this, and St Peters Parish | who died December 5th 1802 | in the 57th Year of his Age | In this distinguished character were united | fine Abilities, extensive Learning | and every moral Virtue and Christian Grace | that could adorn the Man and the Divine | The Sacred Truths of Holy Writ he taught | with persuasive Eloquence | exemplified them in his Conduct | and in the Pastoral Office | approved himself the faithful Shepherd of his Flock | With judicious Skill and fostering Care | the youthful Mind through the Paths of Instruction | and formd the rising Thought to virtuous Action | of Manners most conciliating and engaging | each social and domestic Virtue shone conspicuous | in the various extensions | of Affection, Benevolence and Charity | After a Residence of 28 years in this Island | he was suddenly summoned hence to the pure Joys of a better World | and quitted the stage of Life | beloved respected and lamented by the whole Community | To perpetuate a Name of so much worth | (5 lines)
Decoration: decorative framework, topped by angel, two women and a medallion with head and shoulders of a man

Inscription: Sacred to the Memory of | DAMES | CHRISTIAN and JANE ABEL | successively the Consorts | of SIR JOHN-GAY ALLEYNE Baronet ; | "Women in whose Praise | Encomium has to borrow no false Colouring | from Flattery ; | and of whom no Language | can describe the Loss! | with the former he lived six and thirty years | of unspeakable Felicity | and but little more than fourteen, | with the latter | In that short Period | She bless'd him with the Birth | of seven lovely Infants ; |

the eldest of which, | JOHN-GAY-NEWTON-ALLEYNE, | a Boy of Hopes commensurate to the fondest Wishes of a Father, | in thirteen Summers, | was too ripe for Immortality, | for longer Continuance upon Earth ! | The afflicting Intelligence of his Death | at Eton School | arrived but one Day late enough | to spare his expiring Mother, | such Pangs, as she was incapable of feeling | for her own Dissolution | but such, as the mournful Erector of | this three-fold Monument | of the Instability of all human | Enjoyments | for the Sake of his surviving Children | and, in silent Resignation | to the "Wisdom that ordains it, must labour to | endure !
Decoration: columns, shield, and 2 sculptures: 2 women with a man; woman with 3 cherubs

Inscription: West end: Around this tomb, | best the remains of | fifteen officers | & the captain's steward | OF H.M. CREW frigate Dauntless, | who, together with THIETY-EIGHT seamen | TEN MARINES, & TEN BOYS, | BURIED IN THIS GARRISON | AND ONE OFFICER, THREE SEAMEN, | SIX MARINES, & ONE BOY, | COMMITTED TO THE DEEP; | ALL PERISHED BY YELLOW FEVER, | WHICH BROKE OUT AT SEA, | ON LEAVING THE HARBOUR OF St THOMAS, | ON THE 10th OF NOVEMBER 1852. || East end:  This hallowed spot | was purchased & enclosed, | & this monument inscribed | in honored memory | to all who perished, | by the lords | COMMISSIONERS of | THE ADMIRALTY, | THE CAPTAIN, & SURVIVING OFFICERS | OF THE SHIP, | & BY | THE SORROWING RELATIVES & FRIENDS | OF THOSE WHO REST BELOW, | THAT THEIR SACRED & BELOVED REMAINS | SHOULD AWAIT IN UNDISTURBED REPOSE | FOR THE COMING OF THAT GREAT DAY, | WHEN ALL GRAVES SHALL BE SUMMONED | TO GIVE UP THEIR DEAD. [Below this is a list of boys] |||  South side of tomb : This Island at once afforded a generous refuge | & by the unceasing case of its civil military & medical authorities, | the ship with her surviving crew restored to health, | was enabled to sail homewards on | THE 21st OF March 1853. I CoL. Sir William M. G. Colebrooke C.B. K.H, GOVERNOR IN CHIEF | LIEUT. GEN. WILLIAM WOOD, C.B. COMMANDING THE TROOPS | THE THIRTY FOURTH REGIMENT, THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT. [Below is a list of seamen] || William Munro Esq inspector general of hospitals | Revd William W. Jackson M.A. Chaplain of the forces | William Denny Esq surgeon 34th REGIMENT | ALEXANDER B. CLELAND ESQ M.D. SURGEON 69th REGIMENT. [Below is a list of seamen] ||| North Face: list of officers and marines
Decoration: oval plaques painted with boat scene, rope, etc.

This Marble Transmits to Posterity | the virtues | of | Elizabeth Christian Pinder | wife of the honorable Francis FORD Pinder, | and DAUGHTER OF JONAS AND CHRISTIAN MERCY MAYNARD, | Who | Animated by the unfading example of her excellent mother | shone forth thro' life one of its brightest ornaments | distinguished by unaffected piety | Christian humility, and active benevolence | after ten years of uninterrupted felicity | passed in the endearing society of her beloved husband | her tender frame and delicate constitution | fell a victim | to the slow but fatal progress of a disease | which undermining her invaluable health | and yielding neither to | the tender assiduities of an adoring husband | the united skill of the most experienced physicians | nor the influence of a more general climate | removed her in the bloom of youth | to the regions of eternal bliss | on the 9th of Dec 1799, | aged 30 years
Decoration: large sculpture of a figure of a woman standing nursing a babe, a small child beside her

Inscription: In Affectionate Remembrance | of | ROBERT HAYNES, | of THIMBLEBY lodge, YORKSHIRE, | WHO DEPARTED THIS LIFE | FEBRUARY 17, 1873, | AGED 78 YEARS | (3 lines.) | Dove Scarford
Decoration: orNonemental 3D framework, elaborate scrollwork, foliage, motto on scroll

Inscription: SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF | HENRIETTA PEARCE SHARP | the BELOVED WIFE OF WILLIAM SHARP ESQUIRE | OF THIS PARISH | AND MOTHER OF SIX SURVIVING CHILDREN | SHE DIED JANUARY 28th 1840 | IN THE COUNTY OF DEVON ENGLAND | AGED 55 YEARS [ HER REMAINS ARE DEPOSITED IN THE CHURCHYARD | OF THE PARISH CHURCH OF TOR | This monument is erected by her husband | in token of the most tender love | and of the deepest affliction | as well as for a just tribute to one | whose virtues it is not sought to set forth | but simply to acknowledge and commemorate | she was indeed a truly affectionate | and faithful wife | and a most tender and devoted mother | her warmth kindness and sincerity of character | extended themselves through every relation of life | she died after a long and painful illness | so borne as to show that He | who was her hope in another life | was likewise her support in this | living she lived unto the Lord | and dying she died unto him | May God bless her memory to us as an example | hallowed as it is by the most sacred | and tenderest associations
Decoration: 3D urn with shroud, and crest/arms/motto below

Inscription: SACRED TO THE MEMORY | OF | ANN ISABELLA SEALY, | the BELOVED WIFE OF | JOHN SEALY | ATTORNEY-GENEBAL OF THIS ISLAND | SHE departed this life | ON THE 31st OF MARCH 1859, | AGED 48 YEARS | The last privilege | vouchsafed to her on earth | was that of teaching | her husband and children | how a Christian ought to die | (2 lines) | London (maker)
IN THE FAMILY VAULT OF | THIS CHURCHYARD | ARE DEPOSITED THE REMAINS OF | MARY MERCY HOLDER, | wife of | John A. Holder, | died JULY 16th 1826, AGED 41 | (4 lines ; erected by husband.)

SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF | HENRY HIGGINSON HAYNES | SENT BY his FATHER FROM ENGLAND TO THIS, | THE ISLAND OF HIS BIRTH FOR THE | FULFILMENT OF A DUTY ASSIGNED HIM, | HE DIED BY A SUDDEN VISITATION OF DIVINE | PROVIDENCE JANUARY 15th 1853 | Frankness of character a lively temper and a generous disposition had won for him the | affectionate regard of all his friends | "I must work the works of Him that sent me while | it is day The night cometh when no man can work" | AETATIS SUJE XXI.
Decoration: orNonemental chest shape with foliage and scrollwork

THIS MONUMENT | IS INSCRIBED | BY CONJUGAL AFFECTION | TO THE MEMORY OF | A BELOVED WIFE | SARAH ANN HAYNES | WHO | In the bloom of youth | and of health | was in a moment summoned | by the wisdom of providence | from the cares of this world | to | the hopes and expectations | of a better | DIED JULY 30th 1824 | AGED 27 YEARS | Three helpless infants | pledges of mutual affection | the objects of her | tenderest anxiety | and most watchful care | alike deplore her | untimely fate
Decoration: decorative temple shape with scrollwork, foliage

Inscription: SACRED | TO THE MEMORY | OF THOMAS MILLER ESQ | WHO DEPARTED THIS LIFE | MAY THE 5th 1801. | IN THE 63rd YEAR OF HIS AGE | To perpetuate the remembrance | of the many virtues | he displayed | in the various characters of | the devout Christian | the tender husband and the kind relation | the sincere lover of his country | and the watchful guardian of her peace and laws | the benevolent father of indigence | and distress | and the friend of all mankind

IN MEMORY OF | CHRISTOPHER HENRY MASSIAH, | who died IN THIS PARISH MARCH 18th 1872, | AGED 69 YEARS | Blessed are the dead that die in the Lord | From henceforth Yea Saith the Spirit | That they may rest from their labours | and their works do follow them

This tablet | is erected to the memory of | EDMUND HAYNES, ESQUIRE, | late of Haynes-field, in this parish | who died at Cheltenham, | in the Kingdom of Great Britain, | in the 66"' year of his age | It is designed to commemorate | his Christian exertions | and munificent contributions, | in the erection of this sanctuary | after the destruction of the former one | in the hurricane of 1831 | And it is inscribed | with grateful and affectionate feelings | by the Rector and Vestry of his native parish | as a memorial to succeeding generations | so long as this temple shall have a name | and a place amongst them | of the obligations they give to him | for his worth of love | to God and to man

Inscription: HERE REST THE REMAINS OF | MRS ELEANOR FARLEY | THE LAMENTED WIFE OF ISAAC FARLEY ESQR OF BERBICE |Sincere in her friendship | she was a dutious and affectionate daughter | the kindest, tenderest of sisters | in her household she was careful and decent | to her servants, humane and indulgent, | to all, dispensing good | As a wife, exemplary; - | in firmness and integrity of mind | she was the delight of her affectionate husband | the studious promoter of his comfort | his surest trust | and unfailing consolation |Living the object of his fondest solicitude, now of his deep and lasting regret| OBIIT 11 JUL 1823 AETAT 30

AND HER LATE FATHER | THOMAS PIERREPOINT ESQ | WHO ALSO DIED IN ENGLAND, ON THE 10TH OF | DECEMBER 1837 AGED 66 | AND | WHOSE REMAINS ARE LIKEWISE DEPOSITED | IN THE SAME VAULTS |  T. BEDFORD 256 OXFORD ST, LONDON

and HONORA | She fell the victim of fever | three years before | on the 3d of December | at the early age of 17 | To mark the spot where their ashes | mingle together | this tablet is erected by their family | who loved them whilst living and mourned their loss | long and sincerely

Sacred to the Memory of HENRY NOBLE SHIPTON | Senior Ensign of the Fourth or King's own Regiment of Foot, | and youngest Son of the Reverend John Shipton | Doctor in Divinity, Rector of Portishead near Bristol, Vicar of | Stanton Bury, in the County of Buckingham, and one of His Majesty's | Justices of the Peace for the County of Somerset, in England | He was an active and valued Officer, | as well as a singularly amiable and excellent young Man | who, escaping the dangers especially incident of his Profession, | particularly those of the siege of New Orleans | and the ever memorable Battle of Waterloo | was cut off, when on the Eve of Promotion, by the yellow Fever, | after only five days illness, whilst stationed with his Regiment | in this Island, on the fifth day of December 1821, | in the 26th year of his age, | to the very deep regret of his afflicted Parents, | who have caused this Tablet to be erected as a Token of | their affection for their beloved son

FAITH HOPE CHARITY || Sacred | to the memory of | JAMES BUTCHER | Physician and surgeon | who departed this life March 9th 1856 | Aged 80 years | Generally regretted | And Sincerely lamented by his friends | who in testimony | of their esteem and respect | and as a memorial of the loss | sustained by the community at large | have erected this tablet | (1 line )
Decoration: two angels; portrait in centre, sNoneke/urn, hand writing  in relief

Inscription: In Grateful Remembrance | of JOHN BRATHWAITE Esq | of three houses in the parish of St Philip, | Many years agent for this colony in Great Britain, | whose comprehensive views | and consummate knowledge of its various interests | were only to be equalled by | the masterly address with which he conducted and | the inflexible perseverance with | which he pursued them. | The Legislature of Barbados erect this monument, | anxious | that posterity should know how high he stood | through his distinguished services in | the estimation of his | country. | He was born in this island on the 25th of October 1722, | and departed this life in Great Britain | on the 21st of September 1800. | At Epsom in the County Surry | Where His Remains Are Interred
Decoration: woman seated reading book by column with portrait of man and urn on top; simple mantling with a  wreath and a sNoneke eating its tail

Inscription: Sacred to the memory of | THOMAS LOUIS ESQre | Native of Devon, England, | and second son of the late | Admiral Sir Thomas Louis, Bart | in 1813 he settled | in this Island as a merchant, | and died the 9th of February 1862, | aged 73 years. | This tablet is erected | by his affectionate widow |in token of her sincere | attachment and reverence | for the memory of one of the best husbands and fathers| (4 lines) H. Cade, Bristol (maker)

Worth | and to perpetuate the Remembrance | of their tender tho' short-lived Union | her disconsolate Partner erected this un. . . testimony | of conjugal affection | (14 lines) | This amiable and accomplished Woman arrived | from England, in Sept 1801; and was removed | by a Fever, Nov the 19th following; | Lamented by All with whom she | became acquainted tho for | the shortest period

Inscription: TO THE DEAR AND BELOVED MEMORY OF | BEZSIN REECE, | WHO (on his VOYAGE to ENGLAND | FROM THIS ISLAND | TOE THE BENEFIT OF HIS HEALTH ( IN THE E.M.S. PACKET DEE) | DEPARTED THIS LIFE THE 22nd SEPTb 1842 | AFTER AN ILLNESS OF SEVERE SUFFERING | LEAVING A WIDOW AND EIGHT CHILDREN | deeply to lament his loss | (2 lines) In the discharge of the private duties of | life as a dutiful son | an affectionate husband and parent | kind relative | and warm hearted friend | he was equalled by few | (6 lines) | White Sculpter, England (maker)

I GOVERNOR AND COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF | FROM 1885 TO 1895. | BOBN AT BABBADOES 11 AUGUST 1824. DIED AT BABBADOES 18th SEPT. 1897. |To whose beloved memory as the best of husbands and fathers | and the most upright of gentlemen, this tablet is erected by his bereaved widow. | (1 line)

JONAS MAYNARD ESQ | The Patron of Widowed and Orphan Merit, | Upright in the station of an active Magistrate | Venerable in the character of a Christian | endeared by every office of humanity | was gathered mature in Years and Honor, | on the 3rd of August 1781, | Aged 86.

CHRISTIAN MERCY MAYNARD I fourth Wife of JONAS MAYNARD ESQ | An Ornament to her family | the Crown of felicity to her consort | a bright example of piety | in this sacred inclosure | resigned a life of 52 Years, | on the 23rd of March 1777, | regarded by all within the happy circle | of her friendship

To | the Memory | of THOMAS GRIFFITH Esq, | and JANE his Wife; | a Pair | for many years | most happily united | by the Sweetest of all Ties | a Harmony of Affections | whose amiable dispositions | and exemplary discharge | of every moral, social, Christian Duty | universally commanded | the Esteem of the respectable | while an unceasing proposition | of parental tenderness | Indulgence and Liberality | endeared them | to their children | this tributary marble | is devoutly consecrated | with that strong Sense | of filial piety gratitude and | veneration | which can never be extinguished | but with the last | of the . . .  | They were translated to their Reward; | the former, | on the 4th of August, 1795

IN MEMORY OF WILLIAM HART COLERIDGE D.D. the first bishop OF | THIS SEE, comprising ALSO UNDER HIS JURISDICTION THE LEEWARD ISLANDS AND BRITISH GUIANA, | THIS MONUMENT IS ERECTED BY THOSE WHO WOULD THANKFULLY RECORD THE EXEMPLARY ZEAL | AND PIETY THE FIDELITY AND WISDOM WHICH MARKED HIS EPISCOPATE FROM ITS COMMENCEMENT | A.D. (1824) TO ITS CLOSE (1841) HIS MORTAL REMAINS LIE IN THEIR NATIYE SOIL THE FRUITS OF I HIS LABOURS ARE IN THESE LANDS, TO PROVOKE TO EMULATION AND ADVANCEMENT THOSE WHO | SURVIVE "TILL WE ALL COME IN THE UNITY OF THE FAITH AND OF THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE | GOD UNTO A PERFECT MAN, UNTO THE MEASURE OF THE STATURE OF THE FULNESS OF CHRIST"
Decoration: bust of bishop in profile, crest and arms

Inscription: Near this Place are interred the Remains of the Hone JOHN FRANK NICHOLLS I late his Majesty's Solicitor General in this Island who departed this life the 16th | December 1807 Aged twenty five Years. | He was the Youngest Son of JOHN NICHOLLS, Esquire, many Years a distinguished member of the | English Parliament. He married FRANCES eldest Daughter of HENRY MOUNT Esquire in | the month of November 1806. He was called to the English Bar and being possessed of splendid talents | which had long been directed to the acquirement of professional knowledge much might have been | expected from the exercise of them. In the month of April 1807 He was appointed to the office of | Solicitor General and arrived at Barbadoes the later end of November following but unfortunately | survived only three weeks to the regret of those who knew him during that short period. His many | excellent qualities justly endeared Him to a large circle of acquaintances in England, his native country, | but his relations and those more particularly admitted to his friendship & confidence can also | truly estimate his loss but in their beats his Memory will ever have | This Monument is erected by His much afflicted widow | as a mark of her most affectionate regard & respect | to his memory
SACRED | TO THE MEMORY OF | GEORGE BROWNE, ESQ | (died) 30th JULY 1860 I (7 lines ; erected by his pupils.) T. Garr in regent ST. LONDON
Sacred | to the memory of | JNO W. TYNES | Died 1911 March 1857 | Aged 48 Years.

To the Glory of God | and to the cherished memory of John Simpson Powell | who died at Orbiston on the 13th August 1899 | in the Sixty ninth year of his age. | For the long period of thirty nine years (1860-1899) he had faithfully and efficiently filled the high and honourable position of Colonial treasurer of this Island | This memorial is erected by his many | friends as a tribute to his public usefulness | and his private worth | (2 lines)
Decoration: gothic border of leaves and scrollwork, cross pr

Inscription: VIRTUE alone makes all MEN | TRULY NOBLE | In MEMORY of THOMAS DUKE Esq. | TREASURER of this Island. | Whose eminent virtues | as a good Christian, Husband, Father, | Brother, Master, and Friend | Were so Conspicuous | That he lived without an enemy was truly esteemed | And beloved by every One; And his sudden Dissdation, | Was Grievously and Universally Lamented | The peculiar Mark of Respect shewn at his Funeral by the | Incomparable Governor of this island | His Excellency the Ho'ble Henry Grenville | Manifested the true regard he bore to the Deceased | For his private Virtues and his faithful upright Discharge | of his Duty as a Servant of the Publick | Blessed are They who Honour y Virtues | of Holy Men and strive to Imitate their | Examples | Ob : April 13 An. Dom. 1750 M. 53. | (2 lines.)
Decoration: crest/arms, with mantling; cherubs and scrollwork at bottom; origiNonelly painted to resemble marble (Oliver)

Inscription: IN MEMORY | OF | WALTER HERBERT LYNCH, | (organist) | who died 2nd SEPTEMBER 1900, AGED 27 YEARS. | (6 lines.)

IN HIS FAMILY VAULT WITHIN THE | CONSECRATED PRECINCTS OF THIS CATHEDRAL | REST THE MORTAL REMAINS OF | THE HONOEABLE WILLIAM GILL, | WHO HAVING SERVED HIS COUNTRY FOR MORE THAN | THIRTY YEARS IN THE RESPECTIVE OFFICES OF AUDITOR | OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ADJUTANT GENERAL OF MILITIA I CHIEF BARON OF THEIR MAJESTIES COURT OF EXCHEQUER | MASTER IN THE HIGH AND HONORABLE COURT OF | CHANCERY AND TWICE PRESIDENT OVER THE COURT OF | GRAND SESSIONS | CONDUCTING FOR THIS LONG PERIOD (as SENIOR PARTNER | OF THE FIRM) AN EXTENSIVE MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT | DIED ON THE 6th JUNE 1846, IN THE 62nd YEAR OF HIS AGE, | Leaving a worthy example to posterity of the | strictest probity and integrity in the discharge | of all his public duties and in domestic life | of affection to his family, sincerity to his friends | prudence and circumspection | in all his conduct | This tablet is erected by his bereaved family | in testimony of their affectionate duty and | unbounded veneration of his memory

THIS MONUMENT IS EEECTED | TO THE MEMORY OF MARIA ANNE, DAUGHTER OF I THOMAS DANIEL ESQ OF BERKELEY SQUARE, BRISTOL | AND OF HENBURY IN THE COUNTY OF GLOUCESTER, | AND WIFE OF THOMAS LEWIS ESQ OF ST PIERRE, I IN THE COUNTY OF MONMOUTH. | JOURNEYING FROM ENGLAND TO THIS ISLAND | FOR THE BENEFIT OF HER HEALTH, SHE DIED AT SEA | ON MONDAY THE 4TH DAY OF APRIL 1817, | IN THE 23RD YEAR OF HER AGE.

SACRED | To the Memory of | Serjeant Major | ARCHIBALD JOHNSTON I of the I Second or Queen's | Royal Regiment of foot | who | After having faithfully & honourably | served his KING and Country for the | space of 18 years ; with his Regiment | in the Campaigns, in Portugal, Spain | and Prance, under his Grace the | DUKE OF WELLINGTON, | discharging his duties with | advantage to the Service and | Credit to himself, Died after | a short illness at S Ann's | Barracks Barbadoes on the | 14th September 1816 | Aged 36 years. | This Stone is Erected as a tribute | of respect to his Memory, by the | Non-Commissioned Officers and | Privates of the Regiment.  W. D. Bartlett, Sculp : Barbadoes.

SACRED I To the Memory of the following Officers | of the 21 (or Queens) Royal Regiment | Buried near this spot, | who after a Series of Meritorious Services | under his Grace the DUKE of WELLINGTON | and in almost every Quarter of the Globe | fell together with many Old & valuable | Non- Comm Officers & Soldiers early | Victims to a destructive fever raging in | Barbados A.D. 1816. CAPT J. GORDON SEN LIEU GRANT. LIEU CLUTTERBUCK LIEV ADJ SPENCER LIEV MCDOUGALL LIEU MASSIE LIEU GRAY ENSIGN RICHMOND LIEU NORMAN ASH SURG PEENDERGAST. Brave Men | ye deceived a brighter field, jet shall the | pale rose shed its dews upon your untimely | grave, & memory cherish your contemplation | with no less dignity that ye fell before | an Almighty hand. | This Stone | is placed here | as a tribute of Regard to departed Merit by | L' Col. H. C. E. Vernon Graham | Commanding the Reg | C. Ashmead, Sculp. Queens.

Sacred | to the Memory of | Benjamin Collynns M.D. | who departed this life | April 26th 1826 | Aged 68. |  This tribute of grateful remembrance is paid by his affectionate wife :  Generous cheerful and in friendship true He calmly paid the debt to nature due  | Blessed son of Grenius whose capacious mind | Opend to science, to no branch confined | He deign' d with skill'd botanic art to trace. | The many plants that does our Island grace | His Country's boast for Talents found so rare | Who knew him best will heave a sigh sincere.
